title: CPU monitoring
CPU monitoring
text:
Magic: For cells
The %%monitor cell magic lets you monitor CPU and memory usage as a cell runs. Just add it at the top of any cell.

%%monitor

work()


Francis (8 cores):


























Use --persist or -p if you want the widget to persist after cell execution completes. This can be useful as a reminder of CPU/memory used:

%%monitor -p

work()


Francis (8 cores):



























============================================================
CPU Monitoring Summary
============================================================

Node: Francis
  Duration: 3.5s
  Overall: mean=98.0%, max=100.0%, min=82.4%
  CPU-seconds: 27.7
  Memory: mean=6156.1%, max=6165.2%, min=6122.2%
  Per-core averages:
    CPU  0: mean= 98.2%, max=100.0%, min= 92.0%
    CPU  1: mean= 98.0%, max=100.0%, min= 88.2%
    CPU  2: mean= 97.3%, max=100.0%, min= 84.3%
    CPU  3: mean= 97.0%, max=100.0%, min= 82.4%
    CPU  4: mean= 98.0%, max=100.0%, min= 88.2%
    CPU  5: mean= 97.8%, max=100.0%, min= 86.0%
    CPU  6: mean= 99.2%, max=100.0%, min= 96.0%
    CPU  7: mean= 98.3%, max=100.0%, min= 88.2%
============================================================


Increase update frequency for smoother visualization use four updates per second:

%%monitor -p -i 0.25

work()

title: CPU monitoring
section: Context Manager: For scripts or parts of cells
text:
Context Manager: For scripts or parts of cells
The context manager gives you explicit control over monitoring. Perfect for Python scripts or when you want programmatic control.

Basic Context Manager

from vscodenb import CPUMonitor

with CPUMonitor(label="Computation Phase", persist=True, color=True):
    work()


Francis (8 cores):



























============================================================
CPU Monitoring Summary
============================================================

Node: Francis
  Duration: 4.6s
  Overall: mean=98.1%, max=100.0%, min=67.3%
  CPU-seconds: 35.8
  Memory: mean=6232.6%, max=6395.4%, min=6179.2%
  Per-core averages:
    CPU  0: mean= 99.6%, max=100.0%, min= 96.0%
    CPU  1: mean= 99.4%, max=100.0%, min= 95.9%
    CPU  2: mean= 99.2%, max=100.0%, min= 93.9%
    CPU  3: mean= 99.2%, max=100.0%, min= 92.0%
    CPU  4: mean= 96.7%, max=100.0%, min= 67.3%
    CPU  5: mean= 96.4%, max=100.0%, min= 68.0%
    CPU  6: mean= 96.7%, max=100.0%, min= 68.6%
    CPU  7: mean= 97.2%, max=100.0%, min= 76.5%
============================================================


All arguments to the monitor magic can also be passed to CPUMonitor:

with CPUMonitor(summary=True, label="First computation"):
    work()

with CPUMonitor(summary=True, label="Second computation"):
    work()

title: CPU monitoring
text:
Decorator: For functions
Wrap any function with @monitor to automatically monitor its execution. The decorator takes the same arguments as the magic and the context manager, but here the label defaults to the function name.

from vscodenb import monitor

@monitor
def some_function():
    work()

@monitor
def other_function():
    work()      

That lets you track CPU usage for your code in real time:

for _ in range(3):
    some_function()
other_function()


Francis (8 cores):



























Francis (8 cores):



























Francis (8 cores):



























Francis (8 cores):



























@monitor(persist=True)
def some_function():
    work()

for _ in range(3):
    some_function()


Francis (8 cores):

Or profile them using summary=True:

@monitor(summary=True)
def some_function():
    work()

@monitor(summary=True)
def other_function():
    work()     


some_function()   
other_function()

title: Plot theme
tqdm like progress bars
scriptname
text:
scriptname
vscodenb.modulename.scriptname()

title: Function reference
text:
set_vscode_theme
Set the default theme for the graph plotter.


vscode_theme



pqdm
HTML progress bar for notebooks, tqdm for terminal.


prange
HTML progress bar for range() in notebooks, tqdm for terminal.


CPUMonitor
Live CPU monitoring with adaptive display.


monitor
Decorator for CPU monitoring.


CPUMonitorMagics
IPython magics for CPU monitoring.


detect_compute_nodes
Detect compute nodes and allocated CPUs.


get_cached_nodes
Get cached compute nodes, detecting them if not already cached.


SlurmMagic
IPython magics for running code in SLURM jobs.


truncate_colormap



Left



ipython



html_style

title: functionname
text: libraryname.modulename.scriptname

title: SLURM cell magic
text:
import vscodenb # importing automatically registers the ipython magic





The slurm cell magic allows you to run code in a SLURM job directly from a Jupyter notebook. For example:

%%slurm

s = "Hello from slurm magic!"

Not running on SLURM cluster.


Variable values updated in slurm job are automatically transferred back to the notebook:

print(s)

Hello from slurm magic!


Specify memory per cpu, number of cpus, wall time, account, etc.

%%slurm -m 8G -c 4 -t 00:10:00 -A xy-drive

s = "Hello again from slurm magic!"
print(s)

Not running on SLURM cluster.

title: Overview
text:
Installation

pixicondapip


pixi workspace channel add munch-group
pixi add vscodenb


conda install -c munch-group vscodenb


pip install vscodenb









Tip



To enable automatic theme detection, you must add the following setting to your vscode settings.json:
"jupyter.themeMatplotlibPlots": true,
You can open settings.json from the command palette (Cmd-Shift-p) by typing “user settings” and select “Preferences: Open User Settings (JSON)”.



from numpy.random import random
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import time


plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (5, 3.7)

title: Overview

Resource monitor utils

time.sleep(3)

title: Overview
text:
Less intrusive progress bars

from vscodenb import pqdm, prange

for i in prange(10, persist=True):
    time.sleep(0.1)


        
            
                 100% | 10/10 | 0 s
            
            
                
            
        
        



for i in pqdm([1, 2, 3], persist=True):
    time.sleep(0.1)    


        
            
                 100% | 3/3 | 0 s
            
            
                
            
        
        


See a full demo at here.

title: Overview
text:
SLURM cell magic
Run a single cell as a SLURM job:

%%slurm

s = "Variable values updated in the slurm job are automatically transferred back to the notebook!"

Unable to display output for mime type(s): application/vnd.code.notebook.stderr



print(f"It works: {s}")

It works: Variable values updated in the slurm job are automatically transferred back to the notebook!


See a full demo at here.
